description: From Middle English stelthe, from Old English stǣlþ, from Proto-Germanic *stēliþō, equivalent to steal +‎ -th. Compare Old English stalu (“theft, stealth”), Old High German stāla (“theft”), German Diebstahl (“theft”).

entries.meaning: (transgender) Hiding one's transgender status (in general or in specific areas of one's life, e.g. at work) after transition.
(military, aviation, vehicles, technology) Having properties that diminish radar signatures.

adverbs.description: stealth (comparative more stealth, superlative most stealth)

entries.meaning: (transgender) While hiding one's transgender status from society after transition.
examples: He has lived stealth for 10 years.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The attribute or characteristic of acting in secrecy, or in such a way that the actions are unnoticed or difficult to detect by others.
(archaic, countable) An act of secrecy, especially one involving thievery.
examples: [The King] thinks it fit[...] that restitution according to this order be made to the petitioners for stealths committed upon them last winter (273).

verbs.description: stealth (third-person singular simple present stealths, present participle stealthing, simple past and past participle stealthed)

entries.meaning: (especially military, computing) To conceal or infiltrate through the use of stealth.
(slang, intransitive) To have sexual intercourse without a condom through deception (for example, removing the condom mid-act).
examples: “Stealthing” is an immoral behaviour practiced by both men and women, but only punishes men.
